Affordable housing: Everyone deserves to have a home they can be proud of, but all to often this is not a reality for many. From the high cost of buying and renting, to unscrupulous landlords taking advantage of tenants and providing substandard housing. I’ve called on housing developers through my roles on Newham’s Strategic Development Committee, Local Development Committee and the London Legacy Development Corporation’s Planning Decisions Committee to build more genuinely affordable homes.
Young people: I believe young people in London should have the best opportunities to succeed in life. This can be provided through school, college, apprenticeships and university. The voluntary, faith and third sector also deliver provision that enhances the lives of our young people and they should be supported. As former governor at Newham College of Further Education, an external board member of Newham All Star Sports Academy (NASSA) and a former member of the Local Government Association (LGA) Children and Young People; Safer Communities Boards, the issues that affect young people and their well-being is a priority for me and I will be fighting every step of the way to ensure they have the resources to thrive.
Tackling crime and anti-Social behaviour: A safer London is a priority for me. The police are vital for the safety of all Londoners, but there have been too many times they have let Londoners down. As a Cabinet Member for Crime and Community Safety I worked hard to ensure we tackled crime and reduced anti-social behaviour across Newham. I did this by building strong links with residents, the police, statutory and voluntary sector partners. I will continue to campaign for a safer London, more police and greater accountability of police officers.
The environment: In Custom House I have called for more electric charging points to encourage the shift to electric and hybrid cars. While not being anti-car I want to encourage more people to walk, cycle and take public transport which is sustainable, cheap and good for you and the environment. I encourage more efforts to be made to create well maintained community gardens and safe, clean public spaces. Trees are an important part of our local environment and should be planted and appropriately maintained.
Health inequality: Improving the health outcomes of people who live in the ward I represent and Newham as a whole is an important issue to me. Whether it is promoting healthier lifestyles or calling on the local clinical commissioning group to be more ambitious I am eager to see that Londoners get the best quality care and health service provision. Good healthcare shouldn’t be a post code lottery; that is why I want our services to provide the best care possible.
Ambitious for London: London is an international city we have the political and economical power to help shape the lives of 8 million people and build a city based on fairness, environmental responsibility and safer streets for all. We may have left the European Union but we are city which has so much to offer culturally, economically and socially. We can have a prosperous future but only one where all Londoners reaps its rewards.

Yesterday, Thursday 26th October, Councillor Seyi Akiwowo and I met with the Mayor of Newham, Sir Robin Wales and the Cabinet member for Equalities, Tahmina Rahman.
This meeting was called after the events of last week when a teacher from St. Winefried’s RC School, sent a letter to parents asking them to dress their children as slaves to ‘celebrate’Black History Month. This letter was as Seyi and I pointed out inappropriate and disappointing; and did not reflect the essence of what Black History Month was trying to convey.
Back to our meeting we had prepared a PowerPoint presentation (slides below) and a plan for change in Newham which we presented to the Mayor and Tahmina. At the heart of our presentation was a draft set of ideas for a five year plan which if implemented would make the preparation, commissioning and delivery of Black History Month in Newham part of our business and more organic. The Cabinet had a week before agreed to set up a working group to explore how best to celebrate Black History Month I’m the future. This was a positive step but to go further the group will need buy-in at a political and corporate level, both points Seyi and I raised.
We set out how best we could work with this new working group, one suggestion was to make it an action group therefore it would be proactive and not laden with bureacracy and diktats that can stifle good ideas but it should be targetted and focused with the objective of delivering a workable model that would make Black History Month in Newham relevant, educational and informative.
It won’t be an easy task but me and Seyi are prepared to play out part in getting this group off the ground, developing a plan that is inclusive, informative and more importantly steers us away from the misconceptions held by some about what Black History Month is and should be about.
Two years ago a group including myself, Seyi, Rokhsana Fiaz and Darren Steer, held a well attended Black History Month discussion. We did that on a very limited budget with good will from UEL/Birkbeck and the high profile speakers. It just took will and commitment. We are hoping for the same now going forward. Just imagine what more a local authority could achieve, not just with financial resources but through links and reputational clout. We will be working hard to ensure that this is another legacy we can be proud of.

On Wednesday 8th March Newham Cooperative Party welcomed Claire McCarthy our General Secretary.
It’s not everyday members of the Cooperative Party or any party for that matter with the sight of a General Secretary checking membership details at the door. But that’s the beauty of the Co-op movement and the state of play of Newham.
After members had been signed in everyone took their seats. There was some tension in the air as you would expect from the last heated meeting. But chaired by a London region representative the meeting kicked off. There were some noticeable absences including the Chair of Newham branch, Lester Hudson, who we were told was attending an awards ceremony. Nonetheless the meeting began.
The positions not filled at the last meeting were up for contention. These included Secretary, Treasurer, Membership Officer, Assistant Secretary and the New position of Events/Social Secretary. All candidates had to submit prior to the meeting a 100 word statement for the position they were standing for and it was good to read supporting statements and what candidates would do if elected.
There was a point of order or clarification raised whether candidates who were nominated would be on the ballot. The representative from London region was clear that all Newha Co-op members were afforded the opportunity to stand for a position as long as they submitted a statement.
Onto the vote for Secretary, Gill Hay vs. Neil Wilson. A tense ballot and count and Gill was victorious. The Treasurer was next, as there was only one candidate, Averil Donohue who is current Treasurer, they were duly elected.
Membership Officer again had only one candidate, Alan Griffiths, he was duly elected. Assistant Secretary, currently John Gray, was elected as the sole candidate.
Then came the exciting part. The positions no-one submitted statements for. These included the new post of Events/Social Secretary and the Auditors (x2).
The candidates for Events/Social Secretary were Sugathan and Neil Wilson. Both spoke on the spot and gave good reasons why they should be elected. The ballots were distributed and counted. The winner we Neil Wilson.
Finally the heralded positions of Auditors. This I where I dear reader come in. I was nominated by four fellow cooperators and I was duly elected. Thank you!
The second Auditor elected was Conor McCauley and much desired.
Finally the highlight of the evening was the speech by Claire McCarthy. In consistent Newham fashion those who were there solely to vote left and those I assume who were generally interested in hearing from our General Secretary stayed.
Claire gave a clear and impassioned speech about co-op values, ethical politics, supporting Labour councillors who wanted to stand as Labour/Co-op councillors (which I think would be advantageous and I may consider it) and continuing to build a cooperative and mutual based society in Newham and beyond.
Overall the evening was well ordered and considering the positions up for grabs it was good natured. Perhaps having Co-op HQ present officiating made certain potential offenders behave on the night. But we do need more meetings like these where it’s about speakers, debates about policy and positions, development of co-op values at a local level that is inclusive and supportive of Newham’s communities.
Again I sign off by saying I look forward to the next Newham Coooperative Party meeting and hope I will be able to attend.

In July 2023, I wrote to Lyn Brown MP about the problems faced by residents with their shared ownership properties. While shared ownership is marketed as an affordable housing option for first-time buyers and those with modest incomes, it can become expensive in the long run due to rising service charges, rents, and mortgage costs.
Shared ownership property owners are in a precarious situation as they have short-term leases (less than 99 years) or are “mortgaged tenants” who do not fully own their share of the property. As highlighted in the report Shared Ownership: The Consumer Perspective buying more shares in the property through stair-casing can also be costly, making it difficult for many to afford.
I was and am also concerned about the seeming lack of legal attention and protection shared owners are receiving in the Government’s recent Leaseholder Act 2022, which promised to do away with the medieval leaseholder system but is still very much intact.
I highlighted my concerns to Lyn stating:
“Shared owners (or mortgaged tenants) are not within the scope of the Act or even covered by other legislation that is making its way through parliament. Shared owners who own a share of their property while paying a subsidised rent on the outstanding share of the property they do not own are:
•Subject excessive service charges which can raise to 13% – a cap should be introduced.
•Unable or discouraged from selling their share of the property by housing associations who are either not equipped to buy back or reluctant to purchase the mortgages tenants share if they chose to sell their share – housing associations should purchase the shared owners property share or advise house they can sell it on the open market without excessive fees
•Subject to the whims of management agencies often chosen or operated by a housing association – a common good should be introduced to allow shared owners more say and rights in the management of their buildings and homes,
•Penalised for stair-casing (buying additional shares in their home) by excessive legal fees and cost placed up them by the housing association – an affordable flat rate should be introduced, and fees should be transparent and accessible.
•Classed as leaseholders when they have ‘purchased’ a share in a property – their share should be converted to a freehold or commonhold
•Given short term leases – leases should be longer than 99 years granting more security and providing an asset to pass on to relatives rather than the present system where shared owners have to buy extensions to their lease again at exorbitant rates placed on them by their landlords the housing associations.”
Lyn’s response was considerate and thoughtful. I have referenced it below.
Dear James,
Thank you for contacting me regarding the shared ownership scheme for purchasing property. I understand your concerns on this issue, and I fear for the conditions shared owners face, particularly given the current economic climate.
As you are aware, shared ownership is a method whereby new buyers can purchase part of a property and pay rent to a housing association for the rest, only paying the mortgage for their part of the property. The individual who owns part of the property can then purchase more shares in the property from the housing association, sometimes leading to the eventual outcome of the buyer owning 100% of their property and becoming the outright owner.
I share your alarm over the lack of protections and reforms for shared owners within the Leaseholder Act 2022. I do not feel the Act went far enough to overhaul the antiquated and feudal leasehold system, which leaves leaseholders open to excessive service charges and poor-quality maintenance companies.
For some, shared ownership schemes are a useful way of getting onto the property ladder without having to pay prohibitively large deposits. However, I know that for many in Newham and across the country, the lack of proper protections for those within shared ownership agreements has resulted in great difficulties for primarily new homeowners.
For example, I have heard from many constituents about the pain that excessive service charges have brought. Currently, service charges can rise up to 13%, often from housing management agencies providing sub-standard service. These charges are simply unaffordable for many young couples and working families, especially as the prices of food and energy continue to soar.
Moreover, one of the advertised perks of shared ownership is the promise of ‘stair-casing’, whereby shared owners can buy more of their home as they can afford it until they own the property outright. However, I know that many shared owners have been hit by excessive and cumbersome legal fees and other costs placed upon them by housing associations, thereby preventing them from buying more of the property.
On top of this, many owners are either unable or dissuaded from selling their portion of a property should they decide to leave the home, often by housing associations who are either unequipped or unwilling to buy back the shares. This leaves some shared owners in properties they simply cannot sell or afford to leave.
Finally, I am aware many shared owners have issues with the leasehold process itself. Despite owning a portion of the property, they are legally classed as leaseholders and often given short-term leases. This creates insecurity for those living in the homes and introduces all of the problems we know come with the leasehold system.
I believe that our housing system, from rental to leasehold and outright home ownership, needs fundamental and wide-reaching reform.
In 2019, during a debate on leasehold reform, I told the Government of the conditions that many leaseholders are forced to endure, from instances of completely dead water pressure to non-existent waste disposal services. I called on the Government then to free leaseholders from the injustice of the leasehold system, but I fear that they did not listen. I will link this speech below.
https://hansard.parliament.uk/Commons/2019-07-11/debates/329FC410-5C69-40AC-80B1-32D470DB8B0C/LeaseholdReformhighlight=leasehold#contribution-7EBDA717-D61F-4597-8492-D3F8A1B98C50
Moreover, on 23 May this year, I voted for an Opposition motion calling on the Government to end the sale of new private leasehold houses, introduce a workable system to replace private leasehold flats with commonhold and to implement the Law Commission’s recommendations on enfranchisement, commonhold and the right to manage in full. This motion passed unanimously.
I have written to the Minister for Housing and Planning, Rachel Maclean MP, to further raise these concerns. I have asked what steps the Government are taking to ensure that shared owners are given the protections they need to live securely in their homes. I have also asked how the Government plans to reform the shared ownership and wider leasehold sector to end current abuses.
Please do not hesitate to contact me again on this, or any other, matter.
Kind regards,
Lyn Brown
Clearly Lyn has been advocating for the rights of leaseholders and owners of shared ownership properties. Shared ownership can be the right housing option for some, however more needs to be done to ensure there is equity in the housing system and share ownership is not the forgotten section of our housing system.

Elected mayors haven’t been the success that was initially hope for when the legislation drawn up to create was enacted.
As I write excluding the new ‘Metro Mayors’ for city regions, there are only 16 local authority areas with a directly elected mayor, two areas, Hartlepool and Stoke-on-Trent, choose to return to a leader and cabinet model. There have been 53 areas have held referendums in England and Wales to establish elected mayors, out of these areas 37 have rejected the introduction of the post.
I’ve excluded the new Metro Mayors and City Regions because their frameworks are still new and their level of accountability has yet to be tested. So I’ll focus on single local authorities as that is the area I know well.
So what has caused this rejection of creating a powerful, singular position that is directly elected by the people and supposedly accountable to them. Well partly it is to do with power and how it is used and precisely who are they accountable to. Executive functions can result in a power grab that stifles the ability of councillors to shape policy, elect who their peers in to the cabinet and build consensus on a range of other political areas.
How could term limits help? Well short of abolishing the role of elected mayor and returning to the old model, term limits of say two terms of four years would help, in my opinion, candidates be more targeted and focused on delivering their agenda within their eight-year programme, there would be more consensus building, residents would have a choice of candidates, there would be new ideas and new directions which would be open to debate.
Term limits would create a process of succession planning where new and old candidates can set their stall out and make their pitch, set out whether they will do things differently or whether they were continuation, status quo candidates who will carry on the agenda from the previous administration. But whatever platform was taken at least people including councillors, party members and the public would know what a candidate stood for.
To my knowledge only three directly elected mayors have left office – Sir Steve Bullock in Lewisham will be retiring, Jules Pipe resigned due to being appointed Deputy Mayor for Planning, Regeneration and Skills by the Mayor of London, Sadiq Khan, and Lutfur Rahman who was unceremoniously forced out of office due to a number of controversies. What these examples highlight is how once elected the incumbents decide when to leave office (like leaders in non-democratic states think Angola or Russia) or they are forced out due to legal challenge (Richard Nixon springs to mind).
In Newham two years ago West Ham Constituency Labour Party held a vote on a motion to introduce term limits. The vote for limits narrowly missed out by two votes. I had voted in favour of term limits but to no avail. An argument against term limits for directly elected mayors could be that candidates are giving up their day jobs to pursue this role therefore staying in post is a viable career. I would counter and say the exposure, contacts and experience of being in such a position makes you more likely to have other career avenues open to you once you’ve left office which would be far more lucrative.
No doubt there will be those who will say that directed elected mayors have a direct mandate from the communities and people they serve. Such mandates are bestowed on the incumbent with good will and the best of intentions but what happens when a leader becomes entrenched and unwilling to leave? Then you get power plays and internal battles where ‘allies’ covertly and on occasion openly seek to gain influence and discredit the post holder and other potential candidates.
This is not a healthy political scenario to work in, if you are in the fray, or watch if you are a by stander or constituent. The ideals of elected office are that those you elect should concern themselves with advancing your causes and issues rather than their own. Of course ambition, positioning and poisoning (figuratively of course, we aren’t in the Roman Senate or Ukraine) are part of politics but could be partially avoided with a term based system.
To conclude anyone who wanted to become a directly elected mayor in the future should be asked the following how long do you intend to stay? And what measures will you put in place to increase accountability and limit your powers? Any candidate who couldn’t answer or refused to probably wouldn’t get my vote. Power that is willing to be curtailed is more trustworthy and ultimately more beneficial.

Yesterday, Thursday 26th October, Councillor Seyi Akiwowo and I met with the Mayor of Newham, Sir Robin Wales and the Cabinet member for Equalities, Tahmina Rahman.
This meeting was called after the events of last week when a teacher from St. Winefried’s RC School, sent a letter to parents asking them to dress their children as slaves to ‘celebrate’Black History Month. This letter was as Seyi and I pointed out inappropriate and disappointing; and did not reflect the essence of what Black History Month was trying to convey.
Back to our meeting we had prepared a PowerPoint presentation (slides below) and a plan for change in Newham which we presented to the Mayor and Tahmina. At the heart of our presentation was a draft set of ideas for a five year plan which if implemented would make the preparation, commissioning and delivery of Black History Month in Newham part of our business and more organic. The Cabinet had a week before agreed to set up a working group to explore how best to celebrate Black History Month I’m the future. This was a positive step but to go further the group will need buy-in at a political and corporate level, both points Seyi and I raised.
We set out how best we could work with this new working group, one suggestion was to make it an action group therefore it would be proactive and not laden with bureacracy and diktats that can stifle good ideas but it should be targetted and focused with the objective of delivering a workable model that would make Black History Month in Newham relevant, educational and informative.
It won’t be an easy task but me and Seyi are prepared to play out part in getting this group off the ground, developing a plan that is inclusive, informative and more importantly steers us away from the misconceptions held by some about what Black History Month is and should be about.
Two years ago a group including myself, Seyi, Rokhsana Fiaz and Darren Steer, held a well attended Black History Month discussion. We did that on a very limited budget with good will from UEL/Birkbeck and the high profile speakers. It just took will and commitment. We are hoping for the same now going forward. Just imagine what more a local authority could achieve, not just with financial resources but through links and reputational clout. We will be working hard to ensure that this is another legacy we can be proud of.

On Monday night (29 October) at Newham’s Full Council meeting; I gave a speech to celebrate the revival of Black Bistory Month in Newham. It was fitting that I could deliver this speech in the borough I have grown up in and which has a proud history of welcoming many from African and Caribbean communities.
After ten years of black history month being sidelined it was timely that this celebration of black history and culture was once again supported by the council. Black History Month is an inclusive month of learning ancd sharing and is important now more than ever. This is not the end of the campaign to keep Black History Month relevant in Newham but only the beginning.
Here is my speech below:
Black History Month
In this month of October we celebrate Black history month. This year I am particularly pleased to be celebrating Black history month in Newham, after ten long years it has been revived and we are able to immerse ourselves in talks, books and presentations in our libraries and public
spaces.
For those of us who have campaigned to put Black history month back on the agenda this is a significant milestone and thanks should go to our new Mayor and Deputy Mayor for their efforts
and leadership on this.
But thanks should also go to the many who came before the unsung campaigners and heros who work tirelessly to ensure Black history is accessible and available throughout the year. People like Linda Bellos a former councillor and leader of Lambeth Council who pioneered Black History Month by helping to introduce it the UK more than 30 years ago to
challenge negative stereotypes of black people in 80s Britain and Patrick Vernon, another former Labour councillor and founder of the 100 Great Black Britons Campaign.
Black history like all history has its good and bad moments. We often reflect solely in the bad. A well known adage is that black history didn’t start with slavery and it didn’t so it is crucial that this month look holistically at history of black communities and the African diaspora from art, literary culture even the mainstream sport stars and personalities but they should be balanced with what impact they have had on the UK and all its people. Black history is intertwined with UK
history and that should be celebrated as well as deconstructed.
So I would urge colleagues and members of the public here tonight to be brave and venture out to your local library to either read a book or hear a panel discussion during this Black History Month. You will find you will learn alot and share in the celebration.
Happy Black History Month!

I was invited by a friend of mine to attend an Amnesty International organised event about the work done in London to support and welcome refugees and asylum seekers.
Individuals and families who are forced to flee their country due to war, political, religious or cultural persecution and torture are often caught in a legal and political quagmire.
We heard opinions from an experienced panel about the challenges faced by refugees in reception countries which can be less than welcoming. The situation for refugees in Greece and France was described as distressing.
However there are organisations mainly in the charity and voluntary sector who are reaching out to these vulnerable groups of people. They offer advice and support from befriending to mental health and language skills. These are services are in high demand and can help refugees find the support they are often denied.
The audience present were people with a keen interest in helping refugees and one lady spoke of the work she did locally to help them, although she mentioned the struggles she had with her local authority when she wanted to offer a room in her council house to house a refugee.
What I came away with after this discussion was a positive sense of the good work and good will provided by ordinary people who just want to help people at their most vulnerable, who through no fault of their own have fled their home countries for safety.
The rhetoric we often hear and see in the media is inflammatory and dangerous. It is used to whip up resentment and division. This is something we should all combat.
Those of us born, raised and living in the UK and the west are fortunate and we should extend our fortune to those most in need. Refugees should be welcomed and integrated into their new host country. We should actively support them in their new lives here. Civil society has taken the lead and I only hope our government will follow.

On Wednesday 17 March 2021, I gave an Cabinet member update to Full Council regarding the council’s work to tackle violence against women and girls.
Speech
I would like to start by paying my condolences to the family of Sarah Everard. I would also like to extend my thoughts to the memories of Henriett Szucs, Mary Jane Mustafa and Shadika Mohsin Patel and Kelly Stewart who all sadly lost their lives to violence in Newham.
In the Community Safety service, we work in partnership with the police and other agencies through the Newham Community Safety Partnership (CSP) which has identified tackling Domestic & Sexual Violence as one of its priority areas of work for 2021/22.
We have a multi-agency subgroup of the Newham Community Safety Partnership which focuses specifically on tackling Domestic Abuse & Sexual Violence, with representatives from across the Council, working closely with Police, Probation, Health, London Fire Brigade and community sector partners to develop plans to tackle violence against women and girls.
Current work underway in Newham and within the service area of my cabinet colleague for Health and Adult Social Care includes;
- The Hestia Service (the Newham Domestic and Sexual Violence) supports Newham residents through;
- Independent Domestic Violence Advocates/Independent Sexual Violence Advocates (IDVAs/ISVAs)
- Domestic and Sexual Violence Floating Support
- Specialist Domestic Abuse Court Coordinator
- Female Genital Mutilation Support
- A Multi-agency Risk Assessment Conference (MARAC) Coordinator
- Domestic and Sexual Violence Peer Support
- Exiting Sex Work Support Workers
- Hestia works closely in partnership with Housing, Police, Adults and Children Social Care, Children’s Centres and CGL, Newham’s commissioned substance misuse provider in the borough. There will be a new service opening at Newham hospital commencing in April 2021.
- Operation Encompass – which directly connects the police with schools to ensure support for children living with domestic abuse in their homes when there has been the police attended an incident of Domestic Abuse. Rapid provision of support within the school environment means children are better safeguarded against the short, medium and long-term effects of domestic abuse.
- We have a Female Genital Mutilation (FGM) service and an exiting sex work service in place in the borough supporting those women affected by these issues.
- The Multi-Agency Risk Assessment Conference (MARAC) is a risk management meeting that meets four times a month and is where professionals share information on high-risk cases of domestic violence and abuse and put in place and monitor a risk management plan for cases presented.
- The NIA Project delivers services for women and girls who have been subjected to sexual and domestic violence and abuse, including prostitution. NIA run the East London Rape Crisis Centre and deliver support, crisis intervention and counselling to women, in Newham and elsewhere, as they deal with the issue’s associated with rape and the Court process.
Going forward
The London Borough Newham and our partners are currently developing a broader programme of work to ensure that we better understand and tackle Violence Against Women and Girls (VAWG), in all forms, in our borough, as we know these crimes are at unacceptable levels across London. This will include developing a Newham Violence against Women and Girls Strategy, reshaping and expanding services as required to meet the needs of our communities and ensuring that we champion consistent messaging across all partners that Violence Against Women and Girls is unacceptable in Newham.
In November, Newham Full Council passed a motion calling for misogyny to be made a hate crime. The Council voted unanimously for the motion, stating that the hatred of women and girls must be recognised by the law. Ensuring safety for women on our streets and in their homes will only come with cultural change; we need action in our schools, workplaces and communities to challenge the structures that lead to this violence. The national government must step up and take the lead on this. We need a nationwide approach to dismantling the structures that lead to this violence. Women should not have to change the way they live their lives to avoid harassment, discrimination or violence and we will be doing all we can as a partnership to play our part in making that change.

It was extremely disappointing and upsetting to read that a primary school in Newham had asked it’s pupils to come to school dressed as slaves to mark the 30th Anniversary of Black History Month. As local black councillors and having grown up in one of the most diverse boroughs in the UK it was surprising that a teacher had not taken the time to research appropriate and effective ways to celebrate Black History Month and educate their pupils.
Yes colonialism, slavery and both its impact on future generations and countries is world history-that cannot and should not be forgotten. However, there is so much more to Black History Month than the transatlantic slave trade and this was not the intentions of Akyaaba Addai-Sebo- the founder of UK Black History Month. A more rounded approach to the teaching of black history was needed here. Time and time again we see missed opportunities to celebrate black Britons who have achieved and contributed so much, an opportunity to inspire children and make learning history relatable.
There are several good resources available for teachers, schools and parents to refer to,
Paula Perry’s Black British History guide for example
. Even a quick search online about Black History Month will yield a large resource of information including notable figures, diverse cultures and histories pre-slavery which should be explored in a place of learning.We understand regretful mistakes are made. We hope there’s true learning from this awful situation and next year we see all schools mindful of the significance of Black History Month taking a renewed holistic approach to teaching this to our children.
Cllrs. Seyi Akiwowo and James Beckles

I would urge members of the community from all ethnicities to read the book and/or ask for it to be stocked in your local library. It’s informative and a fun way to learn about a subject often sidelined by mainstream narratives about British History.

The flames have subsided and the ashes remain. The charred remnants of homes are all that remain of Grenfell Tower.
As I write 79 people have been confirmed dead and there are others who are missing. As the facts begin to be reported daily we learn that this tragedy could have been averted. Residents of Grenfell had repeatedrepeatedly raised concerns about the refurbishment of the block including questioning the type of cladding, which we now know was the cause of the fire spreading so fast in such little time, and the lack of sprinklers. These concerns were ignored. In fact everything the residents voiced about Grenfell, which was their home seems to have been ignored and residents labelled as trouble makers.
What is most shocking is that this tragedy happened in The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, the richest borough not just in London but the country. Grenfell holds a mirror up at housing and wealth inequality in London and by extension Britain. Below the veneer of nicely manicured streets and exclusive addresses poor housing conditions were hidden under a beautification project which cosmetically changed the look of the building from the outside but did very little to improve the lives of those living inside.
Many questions will follow and the residents and media will demand answers. The public inquiry will investigate but a fully independent inquest would and should be the best route to get answers.
As a councillor in Newham there have understandably been questions raised about our tower blocks and I am sure this tragedy has focused the minds of elected councillors, housing officers and local services to review and reassure residents living in these buildings.
My thoughts go out to those who have lost young ones and people who are without homes. The people of Grenfell deserve to be rehoused close to their old home, community and familiar surroundings. To deny them this dignity would only exacerbate their suffering.

On Tuesday 9th July, I visited the UK’s second largest city Birmingham to meet with Ashley Bertie, Deputy West Midlands Police and Crime Commissioner.
I had read about some of the great work that was taking place across the West Midlands from tackling gangs and modern Slavery gangs. I felt that in my Newham cabinet role as lead for crime and community safety I could enquire about the successes and challenges in this area.
I was not disappointed. Ashley introducedt me to David Jamieson the Police and Crime and Crime Commissioner for the West Midlands, and we spoke about his role and how he used his office to make an impact in the region, tackle and reduce crime. I found the discussion very beneficial.
Ashley then introduced me to one of the policy officers in community safety who was leading on implementing the recommendations from a gangs commission the West Midlands PCC office had set up. What was interesting about this commission and it’s recommendations was that it was very much community focussed and community-led, with input and resources from the Office of the Police and Crime Commissioner and public sector agencies.
I found this interesting as empowering communities is often spoken about but not always done. These recommendations would be different and how they would be implemented would depend on the ‘buy-in’ from local communities and their participation.

On Wednesday 17 March 2021, I gave an Cabinet member update to Full Council regarding the council’s work to tackle violence against women and girls.
Speech
I would like to start by paying my condolences to the family of Sarah Everard. I would also like to extend my thoughts to the memories of Henriett Szucs, Mary Jane Mustafa and Shadika Mohsin Patel and Kelly Stewart who all sadly lost their lives to violence in Newham.
In the Community Safety service, we work in partnership with the police and other agencies through the Newham Community Safety Partnership (CSP) which has identified tackling Domestic & Sexual Violence as one of its priority areas of work for 2021/22.
We have a multi-agency subgroup of the Newham Community Safety Partnership which focuses specifically on tackling Domestic Abuse & Sexual Violence, with representatives from across the Council, working closely with Police, Probation, Health, London Fire Brigade and community sector partners to develop plans to tackle violence against women and girls.
Current work underway in Newham and within the service area of my cabinet colleague for Health and Adult Social Care includes;
- The Hestia Service (the Newham Domestic and Sexual Violence) supports Newham residents through;
- Independent Domestic Violence Advocates/Independent Sexual Violence Advocates (IDVAs/ISVAs)
- Domestic and Sexual Violence Floating Support
- Specialist Domestic Abuse Court Coordinator
- Female Genital Mutilation Support
- A Multi-agency Risk Assessment Conference (MARAC) Coordinator
- Domestic and Sexual Violence Peer Support
- Exiting Sex Work Support Workers
- Hestia works closely in partnership with Housing, Police, Adults and Children Social Care, Children’s Centres and CGL, Newham’s commissioned substance misuse provider in the borough. There will be a new service opening at Newham hospital commencing in April 2021.
- Operation Encompass – which directly connects the police with schools to ensure support for children living with domestic abuse in their homes when there has been the police attended an incident of Domestic Abuse. Rapid provision of support within the school environment means children are better safeguarded against the short, medium and long-term effects of domestic abuse.
- We have a Female Genital Mutilation (FGM) service and an exiting sex work service in place in the borough supporting those women affected by these issues.
- The Multi-Agency Risk Assessment Conference (MARAC) is a risk management meeting that meets four times a month and is where professionals share information on high-risk cases of domestic violence and abuse and put in place and monitor a risk management plan for cases presented.
- The NIA Project delivers services for women and girls who have been subjected to sexual and domestic violence and abuse, including prostitution. NIA run the East London Rape Crisis Centre and deliver support, crisis intervention and counselling to women, in Newham and elsewhere, as they deal with the issue’s associated with rape and the Court process.
Going forward
The London Borough Newham and our partners are currently developing a broader programme of work to ensure that we better understand and tackle Violence Against Women and Girls (VAWG), in all forms, in our borough, as we know these crimes are at unacceptable levels across London. This will include developing a Newham Violence against Women and Girls Strategy, reshaping and expanding services as required to meet the needs of our communities and ensuring that we champion consistent messaging across all partners that Violence Against Women and Girls is unacceptable in Newham.
In November, Newham Full Council passed a motion calling for misogyny to be made a hate crime. The Council voted unanimously for the motion, stating that the hatred of women and girls must be recognised by the law. Ensuring safety for women on our streets and in their homes will only come with cultural change; we need action in our schools, workplaces and communities to challenge the structures that lead to this violence. The national government must step up and take the lead on this. We need a nationwide approach to dismantling the structures that lead to this violence. Women should not have to change the way they live their lives to avoid harassment, discrimination or violence and we will be doing all we can as a partnership to play our part in making that change.

On Friday I hinted at some good news. So now papers have been signed and submitted I can reveal that I will be a #Labour London-wide candidate in the upcoming 6th of May elections 2021. Due to a vacancy on the London-wide list, I was asked if I would be interested in stepping up and joining the list, obviously, I said yes. I will be the only Black working class man on the list and running for Labour so feel it’s important to have that diversity reflected, especially now.
The caveat is unless there is a seismic vote for Labour it’s not likely I will be elected but I’m here to help campaign for our fantastic Labour Mayoral candidate Sadiq Khan and get him re-elected; along with as many London Assembly constituency and London-wide candidates get into the Assembly and represent the people of this great city.
As a Labour and Co-operative Party councillor and a committed trade unionist I want to use this opportunity to speak about the issues Londoners want raised such as the creation of well paid jobs, affordable homes, an accessible city, a safer city, cleaner and greener streets, opportunities for young people, fairness and equality.
These elections are crucial, they were delayed last year due to the pandemic lockdown and it will not be fought in the same ways as elections gone by. But technology has made campaigning from home easier, social media allows us to reach out and engage with people who might not be thinking of voting labour but who may share our values. No vote can be taken for granted and I will be campaigning, as will many other activists, to secure as many votes as possible to keep London Labour.

I’m standing in the European Elections because I care about the future of the UK and the opportunities that will be deprived from young people and all those who currently benefit from what the EU has to offer.
This includes workers’ rights, environmental protection, Erasmus, freedom of movement, the single market and the customs union. Not to mention our shared values of democracy, pluralism and tolerance.
I was dismayed by the initial EU referendum vote in 2016 and I’ve been continually disappointed by the lack of progress in the withdrawal negotiations. The multiple red lines imposed by the Tory government has meant that we were never going to agree a deal that would retain some of the benefits of membership such as a compromise EEA membership the so-called “Norwegian Model” or a deal that seriously safeguards the Good Friday Agreement. Theresa May while appeasing those who want a hard Brexit has jeopardised peace in Northern Ireland and the finances of ordinary people and families who will be hardest hit by a tariff heavy no deal Brexit.
So I’m standing to ensure those concerns are not forgotten in the debate about whether we stay or go or the type of deal we get. I want guarantees for the rights of workers, people from minority groups like me and to make sure environmental regulations will be protected and not lowered but enhanced if or when we leave the EU.

The London elections for Mayor and London Assembly are over. The good people of London ballots cast their votes on Thursday 6th May and right up until the close of the polls I and many other Labour activists across London pounded the streets to remind and encourage the electorate to vote for our candidates – Mayoral, constituency and list. I’m proud to have been a Labour London-wide list candidate, and although I was far down on the list it was a great opportunity to campaign in different constituencies, meet other candidates and activists in person and put in a good performance for the party.
My entry on the list was unexpected and at the 11th hour, but I couldn’t refuse the opportunity to step up and be part of great team of candidates including our mayoral candidate Sadiq Khan and tremendously hard working party staffers who organise and tell us where to go and when. These elections would be crucial, not only would they determine who will govern London for the next three years but they would show what Labour can do in power against a national backdrop of Tory Party rule and a country re-emerging after three pandemic lockdowns. My role as a list candidate was to put in a good showing, support constituency candidates and their teams, an raise my own profile in the process.
I have to say that I have enjoyed the opportunity to campaign in my home borough of Newham, Waltham Forest, Redbridge and Islington both for Sem Moema but also for my friend Valerie Bossman-Quarshie who was standing as a candidate in Bunhill ward and has successfully been elected as a councillor! And not forgetting phone banking on Dialogue.
I’ve met a number of committed and dedicated Labour members along the way, some were councillors and others MPs but all going above and beyond to campaign and get a Labour mayor and Assembly Members elected across London.
I had two long days at the election count at Excel London, handily based in my Custom House ward. The first night was mixed with wins and losses for Marina Ahmad (Win), Stefano Borella (Loss) and Judith Garfield (Loss). The second day was more successful with wins for Len Duvall and Unmesh Desai.
The final count of the campaign was at City Hall with my London-wide list candidate comrades. Due to restrictions we did spend the best part of two hours waiting outside in the cold before we could enter but knowing Sadiq Khan was re-elected as Mayor of London made the wait that bit better. Inside City Hall we had our final photos and chats then the results of election were announced. I was pleased to see Elly Baker and Sakina Sheikh elected as our two newest labour members on the London Assembly but disappointed that current serving Assembly Member Murad Qureshi, third on the list, didn’t get re-elected. Politics can be hard and unforgiving profession. As party we didn’t do as well as we had hoped, although we picked up votes the list results delivered four Conservative, three Green, two Lib-Dem and two Labour Assembly Members. But we importantly maintain the mayoralty and we can do good things during a challenging time and hostile government to make the lives of Londoners better.
I will be forever pleased that I had this opportunity to take part in this campaign as a candidate and support my party and campaign for a positive and progressive vision for London. I remain optimistic for the next challenge and campaign. Let’s get it done!

I was born and raised in London, I’m a Londoner through and through. My story is interwoven with this city’s vibrant history, mirroring the struggles, resilience, and indomitable spirit that define London. My parents, like countless others, sought a better life here, and I’m living proof of the opportunities this city has to offer.
East London has been my home and witness to the transformative power of change. I’ve seen the celebration of the Olympics and the subsequent regeneration, but I’ve also witnessed the stark contrast between those who’ve benefited and those who’ve been left behind. After 13 years of Tory rule, the life chances and quality of life for Londoners are dwindling.
That’s why I decided to step up and fight for a more equitable London. In 2014, I stood as a councillor in Newham, driven by a sense of civic duty and a burning desire to amplify the voices of those who felt unheard. I advocated for better homes, schools, healthcare, and access to jobs, ensuring that everyone has a fair chance at a brighter future.
As a former Cabinet Member for Crime and Community Safety, I played a pivotal role in reducing crime and antisocial behavior in Newham. My 3 and a half years in office were marked by strong partnerships with senior police officers, resident groups, and community safety cabinet members across London.
I’m not just a candidate; I’m a proven leader, having run as a London Assembly List Candidate for the 2021 Mayoral and London Assembly elections and as a Labour MEP candidate for London in the 2019 European Parliamentary elections. I understand the political landscape, I’m connected to the people of our city, and I’m determined to translate my principles into tangible improvements for all Londoners.
Join me in my campaign to make London a better, fairer, and greener city. We’ll fight for a London where every voice is heard, where every neighbourhood thrives, and where every Londoner can reach their full potential. Together, we can keep London Labour and send a resounding message to City Hall: London’s future is safe in our hands.
Vote for me to be your next London-wide Assembly member, and let’s shape a London that truly reflects its people’s aspirations.

Newham Council has mounted the latest in a series of multi-service days of action oblitz attacks on the streets to tackle crime, anti-social behaviour and fly-tipping. Officers from across the Council joined with partners from the Metropolitan Police to walk the streets of Stratford to talk to residents about issues which affect their daily lives.
During the three days of action, officers were joined by Cabinet lead for Crime and Community Safety, Councillor James Beckles, who saw first-hand the impact such events can have on the local environment and residents. He said: “We are determined to make the streets of Newham safer for all. That means getting out into the community, talking to people about the issues affecting them and what could be done to make their lives safer and more pleasant. “During these three days our teams have tackled everything from crime and vandalism to anti-social behaviour like littering, street drinking and inconsiderate parking. We have also been reiterating the Covid-19 rules and how to follow them to keep our community safer.”
As a result of the patrols, fines were issued for obstruction of the highway, fly-tipping and waste in front gardens. In addition a number of beggars and buskers were moved-on and alcohol removed from streets drinkers.
Almost 70 businesses were given advice around the wearing of face coverings in indoor settings and 861 people were advised about wearing face coverings in Stratford Mall.
Cllr Beckles said: “Through these exercises we are bringing the Council together with residents and delivering direct action to our streets. Of course during the Covid-19 pandemic our officers will be reminding businesses and residents about the rules and restrictions in place to keep us safe. It’s all about engagement, encouragement and only in the last resort enforcement.”The event in Stratford is the latest in a series which has already seen Manor Park, Little Ilford and Forest Gate targeted. The exercises are directed at hotspots which are identified from analysis of complaints and reports from residents.

It was good to appear on Revive FM’s Community Connect show on Monday morning, 21st February, with host Simon Rush, alongside my co-guest City and East Assembly Member Unmesh Desai. We spoke about young people, crime, community safety and police reform.
Unmesh is longstanding member of the London Assembly’s Police and Crime Committee, so is keenly aware of the background to a number of policing and crime issues affecting east London. In my capacity as cabinet member for crime and.community safety I have direct insight into the council’s efforts to tackle ASB and crime working alongside the police. We both share a desire to tackle these issues for our constituents, however we cannot do so where trust and confidence in the police is questionable and belief that the police will treat you fairly irrespective of who you are is low.
In an area such as Newham which is diverse, afflicted by serious crime and has a significantly young population the police have to take this into account and work with communities.
Police reform, a topic we delved into, is much needed. Sadly the now departed Metropolitan Police Commissioner Cressida Dick became the victim because of the slow pace of police reform and the number of misdemeanors and misdeeds of serving police officers who undermined her and the wider Met police force. If the metropolitan police is truly to change and be a force fit to service London and its people it has to be open, transparent and willing to tackle the racist, sexist, homophobic and toxic culture which has led to the resignation of one commissioner and will be a mountain to overcome for the next.

Thursday May 23rd 2019 marked the deciding day of all our hard work over the last three weeks. Polling day had arrived and it was going to be just as busy!
After casting my vote, for Labour of course, I set of for Pimlico to join activists in Cities of London and Westminster to knock doors and get out the vote – GOTV as we call it in Labour circles.
At one polling station I came across a TV network from Austria called the Austrian Broadcasting Corporation (ORF), the equivalent to the BBC. I explained I was a Labour candidate for London and gave an impromptu interview.
We had a good round of door-knocking and spoke to as many people as possible. I spoke to a young man who was thinking about voting Lib Dems. I explained what Labour’s position was and why it was important to vote for us. We had a progressive manifesto and we are the only party committee to investing in our public services and infrastructure as well as a committment to a public vote. He seemed convinced.
After spending time in Pimlico I headed further west to Westminster North where I continued to knock doors with another set of dedicated activists to get the message out that it was polling day and Labour was the party to vote for.
I then headed back to familiar territory to east London. Where I met up with the organised and still active West Ham CLP team in Stratford for a final polling station push. I was pleased to see many familiar faces returning from doors they had knocked based on labour promises and to see one committed volunteer imputing data and calculating turnout. It’s great to have such people working hard and tirelessly for the party they love.
As 10pm approached we knew we had done all we can, although you always have that feeling that if you visited one more area or knocked one last door then that would be one more vote to acquire. But as polling station closed it was good to spend it with colleagues and friends and know we did enough and put all into this campaign.
Whatever the result it’s been a great opportunity for me to meet a number of great people, dedicated Labour members and volunteers, travel around London to knock on unfamiliar doors and talk to Londoners.

Yesterday night was Newham branch Cooperative Party AGM. It was a full house, which is always an indicator of a crucial vote or positions up for grabs. Last night the latter was the case.
Before the meeting officially started there were already grumblings that the time taken to start the meeting was excessive and points of order were already being raised. Although points of order before a meeting has actually started are merely comments and cannot be stated as points of order, these opening remarks gave a clue to how the meeting would therefore proceed.
After a long awaited start, Gill Hay the former Chair giving time for more delegates to attend and allowing time for an informal discussion, the meeting began. Officers’ reports a normal formality were agreed as read, partially due to the time but mainly to get to the real meat of the evening – votes for officer positions!
Now the chair of Newham branch would be the most hotly contested position and their were two sets of slates (lists of preferred candidates) for each position.
Slates are a political tool in politics depending on your political stance, who you’re friends with, who you don’t like or if you just want to get on, slates are used to select candidates for positions. I of course am just a humble observer and an impartial voter who just wants to see the best person in the role who has a ‘genuine’interest in cooperative principles.
Back to the race. The two candidates for Chair, Gill Hay and Lester Hudson, gave their speeches and then ballot papers were handed out. There was some snubbing of ballot papers but as they say “politics is personal and the personal is politics”. It wouldn’t be a real election unless there were contested results and excessive ballot papers and there were plenty. This continued throughout the evening.
The votes finally came back and Lester Hudson was elected to be the new Chair.
Next elections were for vice-chair which were two positions. The candidates Ayesha Choudhary, Jeanette Dye and Mehmood Mirza set out their positions. Votes were cast and the results for the two vice-chair went to Ayesha Choudhary and Jeanette Dye.
Then there was the position of Secretary. Gill Hay, recently the Chair, stood against Lakmini Shah. Ballot papers were handed out, returned, votes counted and discrepancies found. Too many people had voted and two had mistakenly voted for candidates in the next election for Treasury, which was Averil Donoghue vs Aleen Alarice.
The vote was rerun but it was a tie – 34/34 – and as the meeting was nearing 21:45 and well past the tolerance of delegates attending it was time to go and officers elected at the last AGM would remain in place until the AGM was recalled whom to complete the votes. For the record I remain one of the auditors of Newham Coop Party branch.
Personally I want any political organisation in Newham to do three things – 1) meet regularly, 2) be well managed and 3) encourage meaningful discussions. Politics can be bland enough without all the procedural chicanery, infighting and un-Coop-erative (see what I did there) behaviour.
People switch off because of it and lose interest in politics. The borough is changing rapidly and if newer residents and established ones are not involved or feel they cannot get involved in local politics without witnessing political grenades exploding before their eyes they will reject the status quo.
For evidence of these comments look at the current state of the Labour Party where no seat right now is a certainty; none more so than in Scotland where the party has been virtually wiped out (in Westminster representation).
One suggestion would be that out branch sends a delegate to the Cooperative Party national AGM and report back to members verbally and in writing for those not in attendance on what was discussed, what workshops they attended and how we might incorporate some best practice in Newham. This would to some degree encourage discussion about wider policies at play outside the borough and we might forge links with neighbouring branches and hold discussions. Lofty ideas I know but isn’t that what politics is about?…
I look forward to the next meeting of Newham’s Coop Party branch. I hope it will be good and ripe with discussion about Cooperative principles and ideas.

Dear Member,
The last four months have been challenging as the Covid 19 pandemic and lockdown has meant many of us have spent months apart from friends, family and loved ones. It has also meant that as a branch we have not had the opportunity to meet in person. However, as one of your Labour Councillors for Custom House along with my colleagues Councillor Pat Holland and Councillor Sarah Ruiz we have been working hard to ensure we represent you effectively and resolve issues you raise with us. Below is a summary of my work and activities.
Local ward work
Cases have included:
- Handling reports of local antisocial behaviour
- Responding to a complaint regarding a council contract supply repair team
- Responding to and raising with the highways and repairs teams a leak and flood of garages.
- Reports of squatters using a vacant property near Leslie Road
- Responding to concerns about people not socially distancing and a lockdown party in a garden in the ward.
- Visited 3- 5&9 Freemasons Road to see the work undertaken to refresh and provide the former shop units as a facility for nurses working at the Nightingale Hospital at ExCel, and other beneficial uses for local people including a community kitchen.
Council activities and Coronavirus
Coronavirus has meant that Council had to change how it delivered services to residents in Newham. Due to Government guidance on social distance much of the council’s work including my own has been done online and remotely. The council’s main focus during lockdown was ensuring people were adhering to government guidelines and groups most vulnerable to the effects of coronavirus were shield.
My colleague Councillor Sarah Ruiz and I set up the Custom House Covid 19 support group so that we could bring together members of the community and share information about people in need in the local area. The level of response and kind heartedness has been immense and it is to the credit of Custom House that there is such community spirit and willingness to help locally.
In Newham, sadly, we had the highest rates of infection and the largest death rate. Only the science is still to be conclusive on all areas of the impact of Covid 19 we know that people from a Black, Asian and minority ethnic (BAME) minority background are more likely to be affected by Covid 19. Newham is 75% BAME and this can be exacerbated by poor housing, multi-generational housing, underlying health conditions and job type i.e. working on the frontline and in roles with increased exposure to the virus – drivers, nurses, cleaners etc.
The rate of infection in the borough has since gone down but the risks remain so it is important to remain safe and follow government guidelines, even if ministers and their advisers do not.
Within my cabinet portfolio area of crime and community safety there have been challenges. The council’s community safety team has been relieved of its enforcement powers under the coronavirus legislation and it has been the primary role of the police to enforce social distancing. The community safety team has been commendable during lockdown with regular visits to parks and open spaces daily and on occasion advising people to go home and socially distance.
Our 16 council funded police officers have also been patrolling the borough ensuring lockdown guidance were being followed and working with their North-East borough command unit (Newham & Waltham Forest) police colleagues ensuring the borough was adequately policed. There were some incidences – one resulting in the death of a young man in Custom House – David Gomoh, an NHS worker. The perpetrators have been caught and charged, but this does not make up for the loss of a young man who was working within our NHS to keep us safe.
Newham subsequently had increased numbers of police from their violence suppression unit and we saw dramatic decrease in violent crime across the borough. As we emerge from lockdown it will be the responsibility of my portfolio area – community safety, other council colleagues and the police to ensure we provide the security and confidence our residents deserve both in Custom House and the wider borough.
There has been some positive news. The police conducted a number of raids on the 8th July in Newham. They arrested 21 people for drug offences and removed lethal Class A and Class B drugs off our streets and confiscated offensive weapons. The operation known as Operation Swona, was the result of the council’s community safety team and police working together using reports from local residents about antisocial behaviour and the police gathering eight-months worth of information about local drug dealers in Stratford. Many residents will sleep soundly knowing their raised concerns contributed to making their area safer.
I was fortunate to have the opportunity to be interviewed live on air for Revive FM’s morning Drive Time programme about my role as a councillor in Custom House, my cabinet portfolio and Newham’s response to coronavirus pandemic. It has been challenging but I conveyed the response in Newham has been to galvanise the community and ensure no one is left with the help and support they need at such a difficult time.
A New Labour Leader
On the 4th April Keir Starmer was announced the new Leader of the Labour Party with Angela Rayner elected as Deputy Leader. Keir promised during his campaign that he would work to unite the party and since his election he has formed a shadow cabinet of capable MPs to take the fight to the Tories. None of this will be easy, Labour suffered a crushing defeat in December 2019 so rebuilding trust and confidence in the electorate and in the seats we lost will be crucial to our path back to government.
Black Lives Matter
The tragic and horrific death of George Floyd in Minneapolis in the United States. This tragic loss of life through police brutality has led to mass demonstration in the States and globally as protesters call for greater equality for Black people and call for the end of police brutality under the banner of the Black Lives Matter Movement.
Councillor Terry Paul, Cabinet member for Finance, and I wrote an article in response to this tragic event and laid out an action plan for the Labour Party to affect change. Our article “The legacy of subjugation corrupts American society – and shows us why we need to put our own house in order too” can be found here – http://progressonline.org.uk/the-legacy-of-subjugation-corrupts-american-society-and-shows-us-why-we-need-to-put-our-own-house-in-order-too/
Further details and help
Due to the coronavirus and lockdown I haven’t been able to attend my usual resident surgeries in Custom House Library, and I have to say I am missing them. But I have been able to engage local residents on email and Zoom. If you need to get in touch with me or have any concerns that you would like to discuss please contact me on email –James.Beckles@newham.gov.uk.
Councillor James Beckles
Custom House ward

On Thursday 26th January, the European Parliament in the UK held a well attended forum meeting to discuss the future of trade with the European Union post Brexit.
The panel was high-level experts from academia, representatives from business and their associations, a Labour MEP and a BBC journalist as moderator and chair.
The panel discussed what the possible outcomes of anu trade negotiatiomd woukd be for the UK and its businesses. The representative from ADS Group, an organisation that represents the aerospace sector, was not concerned with the prospect of tariffs due to the multinational nature of the aerospace sector which is an internationally intergrated industry. The academic view was Britain would have to revert to WTO rules in the event they have to negotiate nee trade deals outside o the sphere of the EU.
There was reference to adooting a Swiss model which would be a framework to begin negotiations with the EU. However not everyone on the panel were convinced that such a model woukd be right for the UK. David Martin MEP emphasised that a bespoke model would be needed but cautioned that any deal would be inferior to full membership, which has been reiterated by Europe’s politicians including Malta’s Prime Minister who holds the current presidency of the Council of EU. David Martin with one eye on the Government’s overtures to the United States said that any rushed deal with America would be a bad deal.
Perhaps due to the location and pro-EU composition of much I he audience questions had an air of caution especially small and medium sized business owners who foresee tariffs and the introduction of more reguakation as a problem for their business. One person had already felt the effects of the EU referendum result on their business.
We know that once Article 50 is activated the UK Government will have have negotiate hard to develop a trade deal that caters to the needs of business, people and maintains Britajn’s place as an international trading and business centre. There is alot of doubt about what a deal will look like and what Britain’s future bi-lateral and multi-lateral deals will look like.
It remains to be seen what the Government’s strategy will be however many interested parties all be watching, lobbying and commenting on any trade deals.

At #Newham‘ Cabinet meeting tonight, Tuesday 13 April, we passed our End Modern Day Slavery Strategy 2021-23. This strategy builds on a number of internal policies, current work underway and the Co-operative Party Charter Against Modern Day Slavery we adopted in our procurement processes.

As you will read in the report and the testimony in the case studies of victims the experience is harrowing but the support provided can change their lives
Within our Strategy there are four distinct elements that will be utilised to address modern day slavery – Prevention, Protection, Prosecution and Partnership.
As you will read from the report 95% of those referred in Newham are children and now more than ever as we are in the year of the child we will work with our partners to protect our young people and adults who are victims of exploitation.
The strategy includes work that is currently underway from awareness raising and training of adult social care staff, we have taken steps in procurement to implement the Cooperative Party Charter and reduce the risk of Modern Day Slavery from the Council’s supply chain but there is more to do such as improving our data, collection and insight on Modern Day Slavery and work with the Private Rented Housing team on the increased role they could play to identify potential victims of Modern Day Slavery
In terms of the implementation plan we will consult to ensure a broad range of people and partners have their say on this sensitive subject. Only through more effective partnership working can we protect more of our residents and achieve our ultimate goal of ending Modern Day Slavery in Newham.

We were invited to visit St. Winefride’s RC School in Manor Park by the head teacher. This meeting came after the controversary of the letter sent to parents by a teacher at the school asking children to dress as slaves and the joint statement Councillor Akiwowo and I published condemning this action and representation of black people during Black History Month.
Seyi and I accepted this invite as we were keen to hear the school’s side of the story and put forward our view for how they could move forward to cover Black History Month in a more holistic way.
On the morning of the 31st October we arrived at St. Winefride’s and were greeted by Paul Underwood the head teacher of the school, we were also introduced to the deputy head teacher, school governors including the chair of governors, a parent governor and a representative from the diocese.
The meeting was cordial and we were given a background to the incident in question. During the meeting we were shown a portfolio of Black History Month activites that had been planned for this year and told about BHM events that had happened in previous years. There was the sense that this incident had shocked and embarrassed the school and the reputational damage would be very hard to live down despite work done in previous years. Seyi and I set out our initial reaction to what had happened and the need for us to speak up about this incident as elected representatives. We also offered advice about how this might be avoided in the future. To their credit the school were receptive and were reviewing their procedures to avoid a similar incident in the future.
Although these measures could not take away from what occurred it did show consideration and understanding of the situation and a need to repair trust with parents.
Before leaving the school we were given a tour, where we met a number of students and their teachers. Like most schools in Newham, St. Winefride’s has a diverse school population and there was, on first impressions, an indication the school sought to reflect that.
We cannot say what the outcome of any investigation on the teacher will be and it isn’t our place to pass judgement here. But we came away with a sense the school wants to work with us and move past this incident. They also, crucially, do not want a repeat of what happened.

I attended a thought provoking discussion – Is Britain ready for a Black Prime Minister? – a question posed by the BBC documentary of the same name for the #BlackandBritish series which is highlighting the rich and culturally diverse history of Black people in Britain.
There was a lot of discussion of the challenges and the historical bias and rascism which shaped Black experience in the U.K. Now I would urge for us to start to promote and build the networks formal and informal, businesses small medium and large to create a solid base not just for a Black Prime Minister but for the community. This is already being done but at pace which is too slow for many. Many of us in the Black community want to see steady progress and fast.

As we leave behind the seventh week of the UK Lockdown, I reflect on what has been a challenging time for me, as a councilor and cabinet member, the borough of Newham and the country. It is times like this where you have to capture briefly what has happened, what you’ve done and what comes next before the memories fade and the exercises are forgotten.
Firstly being in lockdown and avoiding travelling any long distances has been a change of pace for me. Like most people my normal daily routine involves getting ready in the morning and travelling to the office. Instead my new office are the rooms in my flat, the flexibility of which depends how much light is coming through the windows, a very important factor especially during remote Zoom meetings.
The whole structure around work has changed for many people. A number of people have been furloughed or are working from home. Many others have lost their jobs because their employers, organisations or firms would not or could not afford to keep them at home. Some due to insecure work and zero hour contracts are in a quandry not able to claim the benefits the government have allocated.
Coronavirus has changed the dynamic of work. Employers should ask the question do all workers need to be in the office if they have the capacity to work from home? Allowing some workers to continue to work from home could ease congestion on transport as well as minimise the risks of coronavirus spread.
As a councillor my role has been tested. My normal twice monthly resident surgeries have been put on hold until the lockdown ends. I still try to communicate to residents and the wider political movement through Facebook, Twitter and our new lockdown tool of choice Zoom. But there is nothing quite like meeting residents and other stakeholders face to face. I stay engaged with my ward through the Custom House Covid Support WhatsApp group I set up which has taken on a communitarian life of its own. In my role as the cabinet member for crime and community safety, I have been involved in discussions about how our borough respond to the pandemic and how we monitor and work with the police to enforce the soci distancing guidelines set by government. The latter part has proved to be highly contentious with a number of people intentionally disobeying the guidelines and flagrantly congregating in public spaces. I accept that the guidelines set may set harsh and imposing on our rights to travel and go where we please with whom we please but the measures save lives and stop the spread of the virus. Newham has already suffered a heavy toll with the number of infections and deaths the highest in London. The UK due to short-sightedness and poor preparation by the government has the highest number of COVID-19 related death due in some part to the complexities and diversity of our borough population – predominantly black and minority ethnic, high levels of poverty, multi-generational households, overcrowded dwellings, poverty and workers in front line and public facing jobs. This factored with some individuals and groups choosing not to or unable to socially distance has detrimentally impacted our borough.
On matters of enforcement and ensuring people socially distance there has been much criticism of the police and the council for not being tougher on those who breach the guidelines. The police have chosen to take an even handed approach, although in the early days of the lockdown members of the public complained some police forces were being too over zealous. I’m of the view that the guidelines were mixed in the beginning but we now have a good grasp of what is and isn’t acceptable and doing actions to the contrary is a matter of choice rather than clarity of message. But should the police take a tougher stance and more importantly would that be welcomed or seen as over reach? These are some of questions I’ve faced on conversations with the community safety team and police as they patrol, observe, warn and report incidents in breach of guidelines. It’s not an easy task and has been met with mixed reviews some of which I take on board, sometimes reluctantly. I will advocate that my service are dealing with a difficult task without the necessary government issued powers enforce infractions but it remains an exercise of crisis management during an unexpected event.
The Prime Minister, Boris Johnson, is expected today to set out some easing on the restrictions and a plan to restart society. There will be arguments that we should not rush and gradually bring people back to work, shops reopening and move society forward. If there is a second wave we will be back at square one, so it’s crucial that all possibilities are explored, a coherent plan published and the public made aware of the risks and benefits. Never before has public health been a national topic of discussion as it is now. The public, civil society and political establishment have to question to what degree should we return to normal, what does that look like and should we go back to the why things were? On evidence we now have a “new normal” and going back to how things used to be should not be an option.
